title: Lesson 6: Introduction to Molecules and Atomicity
content:
Lesson 6: Introduction to Molecules and Atomicity

When Atoms Team Up!

The air is full of oxygen atoms, so why do we write the formula for the oxygen we breathe as O₂, and not just O?

It turns out that most atoms are not lone wolves! They are very social and prefer to be bonded together with other atoms. A single oxygen atom on its own is unstable and reactive. To become stable, it "holds hands" with another oxygen atom. This stable, two-atom team is what we actually breathe. Let's explore these teams of atoms, called molecules.

What Exactly is a Molecule?

If atoms are the letters of the chemical alphabet, then molecules are the words they form. A molecule is the smallest particle of an element or a compound that can exist on its own and still show the properties of that substance.

A molecule is a group of two or more atoms that are chemically bonded together.

If you divide a molecule further, it breaks apart into individual atoms, and you lose the properties of the original substance. For example, a single molecule of water (H₂O) is still water, but if you split it, you just get hydrogen and oxygen atoms, which are not water!

Molecules of Elements: Same-Atom Teams

Sometimes, atoms of the same element bond together to form molecules. The number of atoms in one such molecule is called its atomicity.

Monoatomic

(Atomicity = 1)

These exist as single, independent atoms. Example: Helium (He).

Diatomic

(Atomicity = 2)

Exist as pairs of atoms. Example: Oxygen (O₂).

Triatomic

(Atomicity = 3)

Exist in groups of three. Example: Ozone (O₃).

Polyatomic

(Atomicity > 3)

Exist in larger groups. Example: Sulphur (S₈).

Molecules of Compounds: Mixed-Atom Teams

When atoms of different elements join together in definite proportions, they form molecules of a compound. The team members are now from different "teams"!

Water (H₂O)

A team of two Hydrogen atoms and one Oxygen atom.

Carbon Dioxide (CO₂)

A team of one Carbon atom and two Oxygen atoms.

Lesson Summary

Molecule of an ELEMENT

Atoms of the same type bonded together.

e.g., N₂, O₂, H₂

Molecule of a COMPOUND

Atoms of different types bonded together.

e.g., CO₂, H₂O, NH₃

Atomicity is simply the total count of atoms in any single molecule.
questions:
Lesson 6: Check Your Understanding

Q. 1 In simple terms, what is a molecule?

Answer:

A molecule is a group of two or more atoms that are chemically bonded together. It is the smallest particle of a substance that can exist independently and still have the properties of that substance.

Q. 2 What is the difference between a molecule of an element and a molecule of a compound? Give one example of each.

Answer:

  • A molecule of an element consists of atoms of the same type bonded together.
    Example: Oxygen (O₂), Nitrogen (N₂).
  • A molecule of a compound consists of atoms of different types bonded together in a fixed ratio.
    Example: Water (H₂O), Carbon Dioxide (CO₂).

Q. 3 What is meant by the 'atomicity' of a molecule?

Answer:

Atomicity is the total number of atoms present in one molecule of a substance.

Q. 4 Determine the atomicity of the following molecules:
a) Helium (He)
b) Ozone (O₃)
c) Hydrogen (H₂)
d) Sulphur (S₈)

Answer:

  • Helium (He): Atomicity is 1 (Monoatomic).
  • Ozone (O₃): Atomicity is 3 (Triatomic).
  • Hydrogen (H₂): Atomicity is 2 (Diatomic).
  • Sulphur (S₈): Atomicity is 8 (Polyatomic).

Q. 5 Give two examples of diatomic molecules.

Answer (any two):

Hydrogen (H₂), Oxygen (O₂), Nitrogen (N₂), Chlorine (Cl₂), Hydrogen Chloride (HCl).

Q. 6 The molecule for ammonia is NH₃. What elements is it made of and what is its atomicity?

Answer:

  • Elements: It is made of Nitrogen (N) and Hydrogen (H).
  • Atomicity: It has 1 Nitrogen atom and 3 Hydrogen atoms. Total atomicity = 1 + 3 = 4.

Q. 7 Why are elements like Helium (He) and Argon (Ar) called monoatomic?

Answer:

They are called monoatomic because their molecules consist of only a single atom. They are stable enough to exist independently without bonding to other atoms.

Q. 8 Phosphorus is a tetra-atomic molecule (P₄). What does this mean?

Answer:

It means that one molecule of phosphorus is made up of four phosphorus atoms chemically bonded together.

Q. 9 The formula for Methane is CH₄. How many atoms are in one molecule of Methane?

Answer:

There are 1 Carbon atom + 4 Hydrogen atoms = 5 atoms in total.

Q. 10 Which term describes a molecule made of more than two atoms?

Polyatomic.

Q. 11 Categorize the following molecules based on their atomicity (Monoatomic, Diatomic, Triatomic, etc.): H₂O, Cl₂, Ar, P₄.

Answer:

  • H₂O: 1+2=3 atoms, so it is Triatomic.
  • Cl₂: 2 atoms, so it is Diatomic.
  • Ar: 1 atom, so it is Monoatomic.
  • P₄: 4 atoms, so it is Tetra-atomic (or Polyatomic).
exercises:
Lesson 6: Practice Exercises

1 I am a group of atoms chemically bonded together. I am the smallest particle of a substance that can exist freely. What am I?

Answer: A molecule.

2 Look at the image of a water molecule (H₂O). How many atoms does it contain in total? What is its atomicity?

Answer:

It contains 2 Hydrogen atoms + 1 Oxygen atom = 3 atoms in total. Its atomicity is 3 (Triatomic).

3 Identify which of these is a molecule of an element and which is a molecule of a compound.

(A)

(B)

Answers:

(A) is a molecule of an element because both atoms are of the same type.
(B) is a molecule of a compound because the atoms are of different types.

4 A molecule of nitric acid has the formula HNO₃. Calculate its atomicity.

Answer:

Atomicity = (1 Hydrogen atom) + (1 Nitrogen atom) + (3 Oxygen atoms) = 5.

5 Classify the atomicity of the following: Neon (Ne), Fluorine (F₂), Ammonia (NH₃).

Answers:

Neon (Ne) is Monoatomic.
Fluorine (F₂) is Diatomic.
Ammonia (NH₃) is Tetra-atomic (1 N + 3 H = 4 atoms).

6What is the key difference between an atom of oxygen (O) and a molecule of oxygen (O₂)?

Answer:

An atom (O) is a single, fundamental particle. A molecule (O₂) is a stable unit made of two oxygen atoms chemically bonded together. The molecule is what exists freely in the air we breathe.

7How many individual atoms are present in two molecules of water (2H₂O)?

Answer:

1. One molecule of H₂O has 3 atoms (2 H + 1 O).
2. Two molecules of H₂O have 2 × 3 = 6 atoms.

8Give an example of a polyatomic element mentioned in your textbook.

Answer:

Sulphur, which exists as a molecule with 8 atoms (S₈).

9Can a single atom of Helium (He) be called a molecule of Helium?

Answer: Yes.

A molecule is the smallest particle that can exist freely. Since Helium is stable as a single atom, that single atom is also considered a molecule of Helium. It's a monoatomic molecule.

10Identify the term for "the number of atoms constituting a molecule".

Answer: Atomicity.

11A molecule has an atomicity of 1. What do we call this type of molecule?

Answer: Monoatomic.

12A sample of chlorine gas consists of Cl₂ molecules. If you could break one of these molecules apart, would you still have chlorine gas?

Answer: No.

You would have two individual chlorine atoms, which do not have the same properties as the chlorine gas molecule. The molecule is the unit that defines the substance.

13Look at the chemical formulas: O₂, H₂, N₂, Cl₂. What do these molecules have in common regarding their atomicity?

Answer:

They are all diatomic, meaning their molecules are all made up of two atoms.

14What holds the atoms together inside a molecule?

Answer:

Attractive forces known as chemical bonds.

15A molecule contains 1 atom of carbon and 2 atoms of oxygen. What compound is it, and what is its atomicity?

Answer:

The compound is carbon dioxide (CO₂). Its atomicity is 1 + 2 = 3 (Triatomic).
intros:
Lesson 6: Introduction to Molecules and Atomicity

Atoms rarely like to be alone. They prefer to hang out in groups! Let's meet these groups, called molecules, and learn how to count the number of atoms in their tiny teams.

Atoms Need Friends

Why is the oxygen we breathe called O₂, not just O?


and unstable. A pair of atoms (Molecule):
Happy and stable!

Most atoms are a bit like people—they don't like to be alone! A single, free-floating oxygen atom is very reactive and unstable. To become stable, it prefers to find a partner. So, in the air we breathe, oxygen atoms almost always travel in pairs, holding hands chemically. This stable pair of two atoms bonded together is called a molecule.

A molecule is the smallest particle of a substance that can exist on its own and still have the properties of that substance. It's the real, independent unit that makes up the world around us. These teams of atoms can be small, like O₂, or huge, involving hundreds of atoms.

Molecules are atoms that have teamed up for stability.

The Smallest Drop of Water

If you keep dividing a drop of water into smaller and smaller pieces, what is the last thing you're left with that is still 'water'?

If you keep dividing that drop, you'll eventually reach a point where you have a single, tiny particle that has all the properties of water. This is a water molecule. It is the smallest possible "piece" of water. This molecule is a team of three atoms: two hydrogen atoms chemically bonded to one oxygen atom.

If you try to divide this molecule any further, you won't have water anymore. You would just have separate hydrogen and oxygen atoms, which have completely different properties than water. The molecule is the fundamental unit that defines the substance.

A molecule is the smallest particle that still carries the identity of the substance.

A Team's Roster

How many players are on a basketball team versus a football team? Does it matter?

Of course it matters! The number of players on the field defines the game. In chemistry, the number of atoms in a molecule is just as important. We call this number the molecule's atomicity. It's like the team's official roster size.

Some elements, like helium and argon, are happy to exist as single atoms (monoatomic). Others, like the oxygen we breathe or nitrogen in the air, form teams of two (diatomic). And some, like ozone, form teams of three (triatomic). Knowing the atomicity of a substance is a key step to understanding its structure and behavior.

Atomicity: The official headcount for a molecule's team.

Words and Letters

What's the difference between the letters O, H, C and the words H₂O, CO₂?

Think of it like language. Individual atoms are like the letters of the alphabet. They are the basic components, but they don't mean much on their own. When you combine these letters in a specific way, you form a word that has a distinct meaning.

Similarly, when atoms chemically bond together, they form a molecule—the "word" of chemistry. Just like 'h', 'a', and 't' can combine to form the word 'hat', one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms can combine to form the molecule 'carbon dioxide'. The molecule is the unit that carries the meaning, or the chemical properties, of a substance.

If atoms are letters, molecules are the words they spell.

Meet the Oxygen Family

We breathe in O₂. The ozone layer that protects us is O₃. What's the big deal about one extra atom?

That one extra atom makes a world of difference! Both molecules are made only of oxygen atoms, but their "atomicity" is different. Oxygen gas (O₂) has an atomicity of 2. Ozone (O₃) has an atomicity of 3. This seemingly small change completely alters their properties.

The O₂ molecule is stable and essential for us to breathe. The O₃ molecule, ozone, is unstable and toxic to breathe, but it's great at absorbing harmful UV radiation high up in our atmosphere. This shows that the number of atoms in a molecule—its atomicity—is a crucial part of its identity.

Changing the number of atoms in a molecule changes everything.
summary:
Lesson 6 Summary

Introduction to Molecules and Atomicity

What is a Molecule?

A molecule is the smallest particle of an element or a compound that is capable of independent existence and shows all the properties of that substance.

In simple terms, a molecule is a group of two or more atoms that are chemically bonded together. These atoms can be of the same element or different elements.

Types of Molecules

1. Molecules of Elements

These are formed when atoms of the same element join together. For example, a molecule of oxygen (O₂) is formed from two oxygen atoms.

2. Molecules of Compounds

These are formed when atoms of different elements join together in a definite proportion. For example, a molecule of water (H₂O) is formed from two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.

Visualizing Molecules

Atomicity

Atomicity is the number of atoms present in one molecule of an element.

Atomicity Name Example(s)
1 Monoatomic Argon (Ar), Helium (He)
2 Diatomic Oxygen (O₂), Hydrogen (H₂), Nitrogen (N₂)
3 Triatomic Ozone (O₃)
4 Tetra-atomic Phosphorus (P₄)
>4 Poly-atomic Sulphur (S₈)

Note: For metals and some elements like Carbon, atomicity is not simple as they form giant structures with a large, indefinite number of atoms bonded together.
